awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Strategic Partnership for Geoscience Education and Research on Watershed Science and Climate Change in the Southwestern U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the outreach, research, and STEM instructional capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will serve as a model for novel pathways to careers in the geosciences for students underrepresented in that field.

The Partnerships in Geoscience Education (PAGE) collaborative between Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute and the University of New Mexico will implement a research and educational project that will enhance the instruction in geosciences at SIPI by developing culturally relevant curriculum modules, support student academic success through mentoring, increase the research capacity of SIPI and the engagement of its students in environmentally and tribally relevant research in riparian ecohydrology and watershed science.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to build instructional and research capacity through a partnership between the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) and the University of New Mexico (UNM). The team collaborated to increase enrollment of students in STEM fields at SIPI and to streamline matriculation of students from SIPI to UNM and other four-year schools. This was accomplished through outreach activities and coordination of an annual SIPI to UNM Day in coordination with UNM?s GIS Days activities. SIPI and UNM faculty also supported each other through the development of culturally engaging and responsive curriculum models in geoscience advancements. This included the development and dissemination of eight models including the topics of drone-based structure-from-motion, development of flood simulation software, geometric rectification, and supervised and unsupervised classification for land use/land cover. The SIPI and UNM team also worked to build ties between the schools and communities including demonstrations with local Tribal Nations, delivery of training at Tribal GIS Days, and applied research focused on local natural resources issues. The research included monitoring of environmental change in the Rio Grande riparian zone, known locally as the Bosque, using groundwater monitoring and remote sensing investigations using machine-learning techniques. The team reached at least 100 students and dozens of community members over the duration of the project while catalyzing relationships and building educational and research capacity.


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Mark C Stone
